title: WeWork Loosens Its Founder’s Governance Grip as It Drums Up Demand for IPO
text:
Text size

WeWork’s parent company has made large-scale changes to its corporate-governance structure as it works to build demand for its widely anticipated IPO, according to a regulatory filing by the company.

The company, which rebranded itself as The We Company in January, said it plans to list on the Nasdaq exchange under the ticker “WE.” It will marketing the initial public offering to investors next week with an eye to begin trading the week of Sept. 23, The Wall Street Journal reported.

The shared-office-space company was most recently valued at $47 billion in the private market. That steep valuation, combined with founder Adam Nuemann’s tight control of the company under the initially proposed governance structure, left the company and its bankers struggling to generate demand from public-market investors, the Journal has reported.

The company declined to comment.

The changes to the company’s filing lowered the voting-rights premium afforded to shares held by Neumann from 20-to-1 to 10-1. The company also changed a clause that gave Nuemann’s wife, Rebekah, a key role in choosing his successor as CEO should he die or become disabled in the next decade. Now, the board of directors will choose the next CEO in that event and the filing states that no family members of Nuemann’s will sit on the board of directors.

The company is now targeting a valuation of $20 billion or less, the Journal has previously reported.

For context, WeWork’s most direct competitor, IWG (ticker: IWG-L) is almost identical in size, but has a valuation of about $4.5 billion, or around three times revenue. It turns a profit, while WeWork has racked up billions of dollars in losses.

Yet WeWork is growing far faster. A $20 billion valuation for We for would represent a little under seven times its current revenue.

description: The We Company made big changes to its governance structure, according to a regulatory filing by the company.
